feedback.p: Incorrect. Lymph transports fats and liquids, and also contain white blood cells, but its role is not waste transport. Websites promoting lymph cleansing are not based on science!

body.p: The human immune system has the ability to make up 109 different antibodies.

feedback.p: Correct. The Lego-like structure of the genes that code for antibodies can be “mixed-and-matched” into an amazing set of combinations.
Incorrect. The Lego-like structure of the genes that code for antibodies can be “mixed-and-matched” into an amazing set of combinations.

body.p: The younger we are, the stronger our immune system is.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although the immune system becomes less efficient when we age, newborn babies have only innate immunity, and rely for protection on antibodies provided by the mother through the placenta and via breast milk.
Correct. Newborn babies have only innate immunity, and rely for protection on antibodies provided by the mother through the placenta and via breast milk.

body.p: Knowledge of some concepts of immunology date back to the plague in Athens (430 B.C.).

feedback.p: Correct. The fact that people who recover from certain infectious diseases are usually resistant to those particular diseases dates back to Thucydides who noted that only those who had survived the plague could safely assist the sick.

Incorrect. The fact that people who recover from certain infectious diseases are usually resistant to those particular diseases dates back to Thucydides who noted that only those who had survived the plague could safely assist the sick. It is true that certain infectious diseases such as measles, mumps and chicken pox usually occur in childhood because a person cannot get these diseases a second time as an adult.

body.p: One of the most remarkable features of the immune system is its ability to respond to an apparently limitless array of foreign antigens.

feedback.p: Correct. The generation of mature B cells first forms during the embryonic stages and continues throughout life. Although only a small fraction of the potential repertoire of B cell receptors is displayed in circulation at any one time, these cells have the capacity to generate greater than 1010 possible antibody –pathogen combining sites.

Incorrect. It is true that individuals are born with an innate immune system that is limited in the array of foreign antigens that can be recognized. However, the adaptive arm of immunity though gene recombination, junctional flexibility and somatic mutations can apparently respond to a near limitless number of foreign antigens.

body.p: When you begin to experience the flu or cold symptoms, it is wise to take extra doses of vitamins C and zinc to boost your immune system.

feedback.p: Incorrect. It is true that vitamins such as C and A and minerals such as zinc are absolutely necessary for a robust immune response. However, as long as an individual eats a balanced diet and follows the recommended daily allowances of vitamins and minerals, their immune system will respond as robustly as possible. More supplements will not improve the immune response and could actually be harmful.

Correct. It is true that malnourished or undernourished individual have noticed a “boost” in their immune response when supplements of vitamin C and A and the mineral zinc have been added to their daily diets. However, no evidence has been shown to indicate that increases above the normal physiologic values have improved immune function and in the case of vitamin A can actually prove harmful.

body.p: Four year old Sarah has come down with the measles. It would be wise for her mother to keep Sarah away from her six year old brother Ben who has not had the measles.

feedback.p: Incorrect. If Ben is a normally healthy child it would be better for him to develop an immunity to measles while he is young. If Ben is exposed to the virus for the first time in adolescence or adulthood he may develop more unwanted complications from the immune response especially from a high fever.
Correct. If Ben is a normal healthy child his body will be able to fight off the virus and he will develop a more rapid and robust immune response if ever he is exposed to the virus in the future.

body.p: Only healthy individuals should get the flu shot because you could get the flu from the vaccination.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Only “killed” and fragmented components of the influenza virus are being introduced in the flu shot and they are incapable of infecting or reproducing in the body. Therefore, it is not possible for someone to actually get the flu from the vaccine. However, the virus fragments can cause the body to mount an immune response against them and this will provide the individual with a more rapid and robust immune response if the individual ever encounters the “live” virus in the future. Because the immune response is activated the individual may have mild symptoms of this response such as chills, fever and fatigue.

Correct. The flu shot only exposes the recipient to fragments of the virus which are incapable of infecting and reproducing in the body. Mild symptoms of the immune response, such as chills, fever and general malaise may be experienced. There is a nasal vaccination against the influenza virus that exposes an individual to “live” but weakened virus particles which may be able to infect the individual but incapable of reproducing in the body. This vaccine is only given to young healthy adults.
